title: AB 250
content:
The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 2290.5 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to define terms related to telemedicine, including "asynchronous store and forward," "distant site," "health care provider," and "originating site." In Section 2290.5 of the Business and Professions Code, terms related to telemedicine are defined, including "originating site" where a patient receives healthcare services via a telecommunications system, and "synchronous interaction" which involves real-time communication between a patient and a healthcare provider at a distant site. Telehealth is the delivery of healthcare services via information and communication technologies to facilitate diagnosis, treatment, and patient education. It includes synchronous interactions and asynchronous store and forward transfers. Prior to delivering healthcare via telehealth, the provider must inform the patient, obtain consent, and document it. Patients can still receive in-person care if they agree to telehealth first. Non-compliance is considered unprofessional conduct. This section does not change a provider's scope of practice or allow unauthorized healthcare delivery. The failure to comply with telehealth regulations is considered unprofessional conduct. Telehealth does not change a provider's scope of practice or allow unauthorized healthcare delivery. Laws regarding patient confidentiality and rights to medical information apply to telehealth interactions. Telehealth regulations do not apply to patients under correctional facility jurisdiction. (f) Laws on health information confidentiality and patient rights apply to telehealth interactions. 
(g) Excludes patients under Department of Corrections jurisdiction. 
(h) Hospitals can grant privileges to telehealth providers based on medical staff recommendations. The Legislature intends to authorize hospitals to grant privileges and verify credentials for telehealth providers. Telehealth includes telemedicine as defined in federal regulations. Applicants for licensure must complete 3,000 hours of experience over 104 weeks, with supervised hours after obtaining a master's or doctoral degree. The applicant must complete a minimum of 3,000 hours of supervised experience over 104 weeks. This includes not more than 40 hours in any seven consecutive days, with at least 1,700 hours completed after obtaining a qualifying master's or doctoral degree. Additionally, no more than 1,300 hours of supervised experience can be obtained before completing the degree, with a limit of 750 hours of counseling and direct supervisor contact. Experience cannot be gained before completing 12 semester units or 18 quarter units of graduate instruction, except for personal psychotherapy. The applicant must not exceed 750 hours of counseling and direct supervisor contact before completing their master's or doctoral degree. No experience can be gained before completing 12 semester units or 18 quarter units of graduate instruction, except for personal psychotherapy. Additionally, no more than 1,000 hours of combined experience in direct supervisor contact and professional enrichment activities are allowed. Not more than a total of 1,000 hours of experience allowed in direct supervisor contact and professional enrichment activities, including workshops, seminars, training sessions, conferences, and personal psychotherapy. The applicant can have up to 100 hours of personal psychotherapy, with three hours of experience credited for each hour. Additionally, not more than 500 hours of experience in group therapy or counseling, administering psychological tests, client advocacy, and writing reports or notes are allowed after January 1, 2012. Not more than 500 hours of experience in group therapy or counseling, administering psychological tests, client advocacy, and writing reports or notes after January 1, 2012. Not less than 500 total hours of experience in diagnosing and treating couples, families, and children, with credit for conjoint therapy hours. Not more than 375 hours of experience in personal psychotherapy, crisis counseling, or counseling services via telehealth. Not more than 375 hours of experience providing personal psychotherapy, crisis counseling, or other counseling services via telehealth, with a focus on working with elders and dependent adults with limitations. Applies to hours gained on and after January 1, 2010. The subdivision applies to hours gained on or after January 1, 2010. All applicants, trainees, and registrants must be supervised to ensure counseling aligns with their training. Supervised experience can only be gained as an employee or volunteer, not as an independent contractor. An intern must provide W-2 tax forms or a letter from their employer to the board when applying for licensure. Supervision for experience gained must include one hour of direct supervisor contact each week. Trainees need one hour of supervisor contact for every five hours of client contact, with a maximum of six hours of supervision per week. A trainee must have one hour of direct supervisor contact for every five hours of client contact, with a maximum of six hours of supervision per week. Additional supervision is required for individuals with more than 10 hours of client contact. Direct supervisor contact can be individual or group-based. (3) "One hour of direct supervisor contact" is defined as one hour per week of face-to-face contact individually or two hours per week in a group setting. (4) This contact must occur within the same week as the hours claimed. (5) Group contact should be with no more than eight supervisees and last for at least one continuous hour. (6) Interns in specific settings can use real-time videoconferencing for supervisor contact, ensuring client confidentiality. (7) The supervisor must monitor all experience gained by the trainee as per regulations. Trainees must have their experience monitored by a supervisor. They can receive up to six hours of supervision credit per week starting from January 1, 2009. The supervised experience must be in a setting that lawfully provides mental health counseling, meets all requirements, and is within the scope of practice. An intern must gain experience in a setting that provides mental health counseling, overseen by a qualified supervisor. The setting cannot be a private practice owned by certain licensed professionals. An intern may gain supervised experience in a mental health counseling setting, overseen to meet experience and supervision requirements. They cannot work in a private practice until registered, but can be paid or volunteer with fair remuneration encouraged. An intern must be registered before working in a private practice, where they must be supervised by a licensee who meets specific requirements. Fair remuneration is encouraged for interns, whether they are paid employees or volunteers. All individuals must register as interns to gain credit for postdegree supervised experience towards licensure, except when employed in private practice. Postdegree experience can be credited if the applicant applies for intern registration within 90 days of receiving their qualifying degree. Trainees, interns, and applicants cannot receive payment from patients or clients, only from their employers. Trainees and interns must perform services under the direction and control of their employer, including via telehealth, without having a proprietary interest in their employer's business or paying for their obligations. Trainees, interns, or applicants receiving up to $500 per month for expenses incurred while providing services in a lawful work setting are considered employees, not independent contractors. Applicants may be audited to verify expenses were legitimately incurred. Each educational institution and supervisors should encourage students, interns, and trainees to undergo counseling or psychotherapy as appropriate, and assist in locating affordable options if desired.
